longest_book.title: La sombra del viento
longest_book.author: Carlos Ruiz Zaf√≥n
longest_book.review:
7/10.

I read this book the summer after I finished high school. I decided to reread it this year to see how it held up 6 years later (d@mn). To my surprise, I rate it the exact same.

It has an extremely strong and captivating start, muddled with spells that are uninteresting or somewhat tedious. Despite being almost 600 pages long, the final act seems very rushed. The writing at many points feels very cheesy too.

Regardless, it‚Äôs a good story. I would have trimmed may...

shortest_book.author: Juan Carlos Onetti
shortest_book.review: Great writing, confusing and with some unlikeable narrator moments. I need to reread it before EOY.

highest_rated.Title: Cloud Atlas
highest_rated.Author: David Mitchell
highest_rated.My Review:
Not only is it a beautifully written book, a masterpiece of narration and writing styles, but it is one of the most unique premises ever. I am so happy I decided to reread this after almost half a decade. Without a doubt, this is one of the best books I have ever read. A marvel of literature.

100/10.

highest_rated.Title: Pachinko
highest_rated.Author: Min Jin Lee
highest_rated.My Review:
One of the best books I have ever read. The captivating storytelling across generations is unlike anything else I‚Äôve ever seen. I cared for every single character, and every single character felt alive and unique. At no point whatsoever did I get bored of the book, or think that something could have been better.

The book captivated me, shocked me, and left me wanting to start all over again. I felt like I was about to tear up at times.

Without a doubt, this is a masterpiece a...

The writing at many points tries to be dramatic in a way that reads like a teenage novel. In general it lacks depth, both in prose and general storytelling.

lowest_rated.Title: The Temple of Dawn (The Sea of Fertility, #3)
lowest_rated.Author: Yukio Mishima
lowest_rated.My Review:
The only thing that saved this book from being ranked as 1 star is the amazing start and ~80 ish first pages. After that, it‚Äôs countless chapters of yapping, weird horny moments, and down right weird parts that would simply not fly in the last 3 decades almost anywhere in the world.

It‚Äôs a shame. The first book is a masterpiece. The second one is really good. But you can see the sharp decline in this one. I‚Äôll still finish the tetralogy at some point this year, but definitely disappoint...

lowest_rated.Title: Things Fall Apart (The African Trilogy, #1)
lowest_rated.Author: Chinua Achebe
lowest_rated.My Review:
I decided to reread this with the hopes that I could appreciate it more than my high school self did. And I did! But still not enough.

The world building is great and the story itself is really interesting. However, the writing style was just not for me. A lot of times it really was a h@ssle to keep reading.

The ending of the book is really strong though.

Overall, 5/10, maybe a 6.

All Books Read.title: The Spinoza Problem
All Books Read.author: Irvin D. Yalom
All Books Read.review:
6.5-7/10

In a nutshell, although the first third of the book is fully captivating from both characters, the rest of the book loses its appeal from the Spinoza side. The dialogues feel eternal and often obtuse. They fail to enact his principles and his teachings in the same effective way the first third of the book did.

The first 30 percent of the book is great. 40-70% through, the book slows down and it definitely felt like I needed to power through. The final 30% was enjoyabl...

All Books Read.title: The Little Stranger
All Books Read.author: Sarah Waters
All Books Read.review:
6.5/10

The book has its highs and lows. You can review by percentage sections of the book:

0-40%: super interesting and gripping mystery. You wonder if there is some malicious entity at play (this is not a spoiler). This is the first peak.

40-60%: lowkey boring, but you could argue it sets up the final act (which is underwhelming too).

60-80%: again very interesting, the story continues and the mystery increases. Another great peak.

80-95%: the prota...

All Books Read.review:
‚ÄúIt is not that we have a short space of time, but that we waste much of it.‚Äù

That‚Äôs the gist of the book, and it‚Äôs timelessly true.

All Books Read.review:
7/10

First half of the book is a really cool and well-written meta story. IMO the strongest part of the book.

The second half is a series of tales, loosely leading somewhere, which, although interesting, could have been 100-150 pages shorter‚Äîbut then you wouldn‚Äôt have 26 chapters starting with the corresponding letter from the alphabet.

All Books Read.title: Runaway Horses
All Books Read.author: Yukio Mishima
All Books Read.review:
Runaway Horses shares the same narrative moments of brilliance as Spring Snow, with details tying both novels together in a subtle yet powerful manner.

The theme of reincarnation is further elaborated on, having been set up first in Spring Snow, yet never too over the top.

There were moments in which I found myself skimming through some pages, which I didn‚Äôt find myself doing as much in Spring Snow. The story here is also less simple, and instead deals with heavier political ...

All Books Read.title: Zero: The Biography of a Dangerous Idea
All Books Read.author: Charles Seife
All Books Read.review:
In reality, this is a 5/10 but for some reason half a star still isn‚Äôt a feature in Goodreads.

To be succinct: it feels like the author needed to reach a page or word count.

In detail:
The book struggles to pick between diving deeper into mathematical intricacies or glancing over subjects rapidly. It never does either enough, and does both pretty poorly. Who is the target audience supposed to be? It‚Äôs at times too technical for someone who is not into math, yet too shallow...

All Books Read.title: Last Summer in the City
All Books Read.author: Gianfranco Calligarich
All Books Read.review:
It starts off strong and then somewhat flattens out in the middle. It can be described as a bleaker, more mature vibe to the narrator of ‚ÄúCatcher in the Rye‚Äù and his mentality.

The ending is powerful. Before the last 10 pages, I was ready to give it a 6.5-7/10. After I finished it though, it easily merits a 7.5-8/10.

Worth the read, in my opinion.

‚ÄúI was dealt my cards and I played them.‚Äù

All Books Read.review:
I‚Äôd give it a 7/10. The concept is interesting, and most of the times the writing feels vivid. I cant seem to like Ruth, although maybe once or twice I do empathize with her. I liked Tommy and Kath‚Äôs friendship.

Overall, not a lot happens in terms of ‚Äústory completion‚Äù. They just lived their life and Katy narrates it. Again, enjoyable, but not sure if I‚Äôd read it again.

All Books Read.title: Shame
All Books Read.author: Salman Rushdie
All Books Read.review:
It has some great parts and it has some slow parts. U fortunately, the former does not outweigh the latter.

I found myself disliking the narrator at times.

Overall, the story was interesting, but I would say that everything good about this book is done better in Midnight‚Äôs Children.

Maybe I‚Äôll reread it in some years and find newfound joy and appreciation. Not for now though.
